climbs.name: Velveeta
climbs.fa: Unknown (please come forward and claim & name your route)

content.description:
p1**** (5.10a, ≈130'): This pitch is a four star classic slab climb for the area and similar to subtly featured sections of nearby Power Dome with edges, dishes, and bumps. Climb the technical slab following the line of 8 or so bolts up to a small sloping ledge and two bolt anchor. The climbing is somewhat sustained and engaging although rests do appear to allow shaking out the calves and mental repose. In warm weather this pitch is challenging. The bolts get further apart as you go along, but this pitch is relatively generously bolted for this type of climbing in the area.

p2* (5.10a, ≈75'): Slight left on easy ground to a downward facing flake that takes finger sized cams before the first and only bolt on the small headwall directly above the anchor. A single reachy crux move (≈5.10a) comprises the difficulty of this pitch; the remainder of the climbing clocks in much easier. Belay at a two bolt anchor above a prominent ramping ledge. One of the anchor bolts is camouflaged with tan finish and has a single rap ring. The anchor is a bit difficult to see.

p3*** (5.10a, ≈150'): Climb directly up from the anchor on a short headwall past a few bolts that veer to the right. Careful not to fall before reaching bolt 1 as you could hit your belayer. The crux is a short series of insecure reachy moves on small holds. Surmount the headwall onto an easing angle and terrain and romp up and left to the two-bolt anchor of Swiss Cheese. The brief headwall is technically challenging and the reminder of the pitch much easier.

Note: In

A Climber's Guide to Courtright Reservoir & Vicinity

, the author, Dwight Kroll, states, "I took the liberty of naming this fine route as I could find no information on it. If this route is yours, please come forward and claim it."
content.protection: Bolts (8-10 quickdraws). A single optional finger sized cam (≈0.5 BD) to protect easy start of p2.
content.location: Rap to the base of Swiss Cheese Wall via the route Swiss Cheese, which is the only route equipped with rappel hardware. To climber's right of Swiss Cheese look for a two bolt anchor that marks the start of the climb and an obvious line of bolts up the thin slab.

content.description:
P1 is a four star classic. P2 & 3 are just kinda "get there" pitches.

P1 is a long pitch of classic low-angled face climbing up a variety of holds and holes (5.8, ≈ 50m). It ends at a 2 bolt anchor at a grassy scoop. P2 travels up easy, low-angled face past a couple bolts and ends on top of a large detached block in front of a 2 bolt anchor. P3 is a long, low-angled face that ends at the top rappel anchor.
content.protection: Bolts (4 draws for bolts, more for pro), single rack tricams small to medium, single rack cams from fingers to fist (#3)
content.location: The rappels approach delivers you to the base of the route. It follows a darker colored water streak with holes. Look for a lighter colored dike/flake angling up and left just above head height that traverses in to the start.

content.description: A single pitch climb to get in before heading back up one of the nice multi-pitch routes back to the top. Heads up obvious crack then through several bolts to a black streak then move right to blocky headwall clipping 2 more bolts to the double rap ring anchor.  Crux is passing final 2 bolts to get to the anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts with small gear to 1" with several tri-cams for the lower solution pockets.
content.location: Located on the far right side of Swiss Cheese Wall just to the left of giant chimney.  A 3 pitch rappel will get you to the base then head just a bit downstream.
